Low-dimensional carbon nanomaterials have been widely used in energy storage and conversion owing to their distinct electrochemical properties and mechanical and thermal stability.[16–18] 3D superstructures constructed from lowdimensional components such as carbon nanorods/wires or graphene nanorribbons can inherit the exceptional properties of their building blocks and acquire certain unconventional advantages.[19,20] However, the self-assemblies of 1D carbon nanomaterials into 3D ordered spherical superstructures are considerably challenging owing to the reduced accessible contact areas between the building blocks and core templates. Although various syn-
thetic approches have been developed for the synthesis of lowdimensional carbon nanostructures with well-defined size and controllable composition,[21–23] no techniques have been applied for controlling the assembly of 1D carbon nanomaterials into 3D spherical superstructure with uniform morphology.
Metal–organic frameworks (MOF) are a class of porous crystalline materials that are constructed by metal ions/clusters and organic linkers.[24] The use of MOF as a template or precursor to synthesize carbon nanostructure is an efficient approach to produce carbon materials with controlled morphology and
Hierarchical superstructures in nano/microsize have attracted great attention owing to their wide potential applications. Herein, a self-templated strategy is presented for the synthesis of a spherical superstructure of carbon nanorods (SS-CNR) in micrometers through the morphology-preserved thermal transformation of a spherical superstructure of metal–organic framework nanorods (SS-MOFNR). The self-ordered SS-MOFNR with a chestnut-shell-like superstructure composed of 1D MOF nanorods on the shell is synthesized by a hydrothermal transformation process from crystalline MOF nanoparticles. After carbonization in argon, the hierarchical SS-MOFNR transforms into SS-CNR, which preserves the original chestnut-shell-like superstructure with 1D porous carbon nanorods on the shell. Taking the advantage of this functional superstructure, SS-CNR immobilized with ultrafine palladium (Pd) nanoparticles (Pd@SS-CNR) exhibits excellent catalytic activity for formic acid dehydrogenation. This synthetic strategy provides a facile method to synthesize uniform spherical superstructures constructed from 1D MOF nanorods or carbon nanorods for applications in catalysis and energy storage.

sections.heading: 3D Superstructures
sections.text:
Hierarchical superstructures are ubiquitous in the biological systems (e.g., proteins, lipids, and carbohydrates). From the aspect of synthesis, self-assembly of simple building blocks into 3D, highly ordered superstructure with novel properties has attracted great interest in the fields of optics, catalysis, and energy storage.[1–4] Highly organized building blocks of metals,[5,6] semiconductors,[7,8] hybrid metal–organic materials,[9–11] and transition-metal dichalcogenides[12] have been fabricated by using various methods. However, the assembly of 1D rod/ wire-like building blocks into controllable 3D hierarchical

composition.[16,22,25–29] Herein, we fabricate a spherical superstructure of carbon nanorods (SS-CNR), for the first time, by the self-templated thermal transformation of a spherical superstructure of MOF nanorods (SS-MOFNR). In this strategy, the SS-MOFNR with a hollow interior assembled from 1D MOF nanorods is synthesized by the hydrothermal transformation of crystalline MOF nanoparticles, which is converted into SS-CNR by pyrolysis in argon atmosphere. The obtained SS-CNR with preserved superstructure can be used as an excellent support for immobilizing ultrafine Pd nanoparticles (NPs), which show an exceptionally high activity for hydrogen evolution from formic acid (FA) that has been considered a safe and promising hydrogen carrier.[30] Owing to the high hydrogen content (4.4 wt%), low toxicity, and easy accessibility by biomass processing of FA, the dehydrogenation of FA to produce hydrogen (HCOOH → H2 + CO2) is a feasible strategy for clean and renewable energy sources.[31]
The synthetic approach for SS-CNR is shown in Figure 1. The reaction of zinc acetate dihydrate with 2,5-dihydroxyterephthalic acid in methanol solution results in the formation of crystalline zinc-MOF[32] (Zn-MOF-74) NPs with an average diameter of 30–50 nm (Figure S1, Supporting Information), which are used as a precursor to produce chestnut-shell-like SS-MOFNR in water with urea as a modulator through a
hydrothermal transformation process. Carbonization of SS-MOFNR in an argon flow, preserving the original morphology, affords SS-CNR with 1D porous carbon nanorods assembled into a 3D spherical superstructure.
Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns confirm the crystalline state of SS-MOFNR, which are in good agreement with the simulated diffraction patterns of the reported structure of Zn(H2O)2(C8H4O6) (denoted as Zn-MOF-HT, Figure 2a).[33] Different to the precursor of MOF-74 with a porous structure, the Zn-MOF-HT shows an exceptionally high density with no porosity.[33] The Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) surface areas and pore volumes of SS-MOFNR are 17.7 m2 g−1 and 0.05 cm3 g−1, respectively, much lower than those of Zn-MOF-74 NPs (474.9 m2 g−1, 0.71 cm3 g−1) (Figure 2b; Figure S1, Supporting Information), demonstrating the different crystal structures of SS-MOFNR and Zn-MOF-74 NPs. Both scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and transmission electron microscopic (TEM) images reveal the unique features of self-assembled superstructure in which the 1D MOF nanorods (30–50 nm in diameter) are ordered along the three directions, constructing a spherical superstructure with an average diameter of ≈10 µm (Figure 2). The details of 1D MOF nanorods on the shell are resolved by high resolution TEM (HRTEM) analysis. Unlike an oriented 1D assembly
Adv. Mater. 2019, 1900440
© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1900440 (3 of 7)
of nanoparticles with lots of grain boundaries, in our work, no grain boundaries are observed in a single MOF nanorod. This is because the MOF nanorods are obtained from the crystallization of the components dissolved from MOF-74 NPs in the solution (vide infra). HRTEM images of the nanorods show the obvious lattice fringes for examples with distances of 0.55 and 0.43 nm, corresponding to the {002} and {21−1} crystal planes, respectively (Figure S2, Supporting Information). Surprisingly, SS-MOFNR has a chestnut-shell-like morphology with an interior cavity of ≈3 µm, which breaks when exposed to a mechanical force (Figure 2g).
To gain insight into the formation mechanism of SS-MOFNR, the transformation process is first studied at different reaction temperatures for 24 h in the absence of urea (Figure S3, Supporting Information). At 100 °C, the product maintains the crystal structure of Zn-MOF-74, showing the morphology of nanoparticles with some aggregation. Compared to the original morphology of Zn-MOF-74 NPs, the surface of these nanoparticles seems to be melted. When the temperature increases to 125 °C, the phase of Zn-MOF-HT appears. SEM images show that all MOF NPs transform into rod-like intermediates with several nanorods assembled together. Further increasing the reaction temperature does not change the crystal structure, while several spherical structures appear among the rod-like intermediates. However, athough the SS-MOFNR can be obtained at this condition, the resultants show the coexistence of unassembled MOF nanorods and a limited number of spherical superstructures even though the reaction temperatue is up to 175 °C. By contrast, the use of urea as a modulator during the hydrothermal transformation process results in the formation of SS-MOFNR with highly uniform morphologies. The SS-MOFNR samples prepared at 175 °C with different amounts of urea show the same crystallinity and morphology, suggesting that the urea is an effective modulator
Adv. Mater. 2019, 1900440
© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1900440 (4 of 7)
to induce the formation of 3D chestnut-shell-like superstructures (Figures S4 and S5, Supporting Information). Even at 125 °C, the well-defined SS-MOFNR is formed, indicating that the urea not only regulates the morphology but also decreases the formation temperature of SS-MOFNR (Figures S6 and S7, Supporting Information). However, urea has not been detected in SS-MOFNR by Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy measurements (Figure S8, Supporting Information), illustrating that the urea might just remain on the surface of the product, which is removed by washing with methanol.
Further to understand the transformation process, timedependent experiments are performed at 125 °C with urea as the modulator (Figures S9 and S10, Supporting Information). At the initial stage (0–2 h), the resultant retains the original crystalline structure of Zn-MOF-74. The phase of Zn-MOF-HT appears at about 3 h, which shows an obvious peak at ≈16°, suggesting the transformation of crystal structure. Pure ZnMOF-HT is obtained when the reaction time reaches 6 h, and SEM results display the coexistence of microsized spherical superstructures and intermediates of assembly with several 1D nanorods. The intermediates are finally assembled into microsized SS-MOFNR with the extention of reaction time. Above investigations indicate that the formation of SS-MOFNR is a stepwise transformation process. The Zn-MOF-74 NPs are first transformed into 1D Zn-MOF-HT nanorods, and then self-organized into spherical superstructures. It is confirmed that the water solvent facilitates the formation of 1D MOF structures. Only nanoparticles with preserved morphologies are obtained when using methanol, ethanol, or N,N-dimethylformamide as the solvents instead of water (Figure S11, Supporting Information). However, direct heating of zinc acetate dihydrate and 2,5-dihydroxyterephthalic acid in water just gives 1D MOF bundles in microsize, which is attributed to the quick growing up of crystal nucleus in a high reactant concentration (Figure S12, Supporting Information). On the contrary, the use of MOF-74 NPs as a precursor will largely slow down the growth rate of nucleus by the slow disolving of MOF NPs to provide metals and ligands in low concentrations, leading to the formation of 1D MOFs in nanoscale. Generally, it is difficult to form a spherical superstructure with microrods in large sizes owing to the lack of neccessary flexibility and rotation ability, while nanorods with a superior flexibility in tailoring spatial parameters, such as the gap and angle between two nanorods, will facilitate the formation of a microsized entity with spatial order and nanoscale precision. Therefore, the synthesis of MOF NPs in the first step is indispensable for the construction of SS-MOFNR in this work. Additionally, similar spherical superstructures can be synthesized by using hexadecyltrimethylammonium bromide or polyvinylpyrrolidone in place of urea as the modulator (Figures S13–S16, Supporting Information), illustrating that the transformation of MOF NPs is an efficient approach to fabricate chestnut-shell-like SS-MOFNR.
Carbonization of SS-MOFNR in an argon flow at 1000 °C produces the well-defind SS-CNR, which preserves the original chestnut shell-like morphology with 1D porous carbon nanorods assembled into a spherical superstructure on the shell (Figure 3; Figure S17, Supporting Information). As shown in Figure 3a–c, the average diameter of SS-CNR is about 10 µm, consistent with the size of SS-MOFNR. The carbon nanorods
of SS-CNR, showing a diameter of ≈40 nm and length of 2–3 µm, are ordered along the three directions on the shell. SEM images (Figure 3a, inset) show the hollow interior of the superstructure, demonstrating that the hierarchical morphology is well-retained during the pyrolysis process. The detailed nanostructure of SS-CNR is investigated by HRTEM and high-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM) analysis, which displays a limited graphitization degree of carbon nanorods with nanopores (Figure 3d–f). Although lots of carbon nanostructures with various morphologies have been synthesized in the past decades, to the best of our knowledge, it is the first chestnut shell-like superstructure composed of anisotropic 1D carbon nanorods.
PXRD patterns of SS-CNR display two peaks at ≈25° and ≈43°, corresponding to the characteristic peaks of carbon (002) and (101) diffractions, respectively (Figure S18, Supporting Information).[22] No diffraction peaks corresponding to Zn-related phases are observed. Chemical compositions of SS-CNR are further studied by electron-energy-loss spectroscopy (EELS) analysis.[30] The sharp C K-edge at around 284 eV and O K-edge at around 532 eV can be clearly identified (Figure 3g). Raman spectra show two peaks centered at 1615 and 1351 cm−1, corresponding to the G and D bands, respectively. The value of IG/ID is found to be about 0.88, implying the limited graphitization degree of SS-CNR (Figure 3h; Figure S19, Supporting Information).[34] N2 sorption isotherms of SS-CNR show a sharp increase in N2 uptakes at a low relative pressure and a remarkable hysteresis loop in high-relative-pressure regions (0.5–1.0), indicating the existence of different pore sizes ranging from micropores to mesopores (Figure 3i; Figure S20, Supporting Information). The pore size distribution curve shows three peaks located at 1.6, 5, and 45 nm, further demonstrating the hierarchically porous structure of the sample. SS-CNR exhibits an ultrahigh BET surface area (SBET) of ≈2350 m2 g−1 and pore volume (Vp) of 2.0 cm3 g−1, much larger than those of carbon nanoparticles (CNP) (SBET = 1370 m2 g−1, Vp = 1.7 cm3 g−1) derived from Zn-MOF-74 NPs (Figures S21 and S22 and Table S1, Supporting Information). Energy-dispersive spectroscopic (EDS) measurements reveal the existence of C and O in the sample, consistent with the EELS results (Figure S23, Supporting Information). No nitrogen is detected by EELS and EDS in the sample, further confirming that no urea remains in SS-MOFNR.
SS-CNR has been used as a high-performance support to immobilize highly dispersed Pd nanoparticles[35,36] with an average size of about 2.8 nm (Figure 4a–e; Figures S24 and S25, Supporting Information). EELS spectra reveal the existence of C, Pd, and O in the sample, in agreement with the X-ray photoelectron spectroscopic results (Figure 4f; Figure S26, Supporting Information). Pd@SS-CNR shows a BET surface area of 2100 m2 g−1 and a pore volume of 1.7 cm3 g−1 (Figure S27, Supporting Information). A high porosity of catalysts facilitates the difussion of reactants and products during the reactions. Inductively coupled plasma–optical emission spectroscopy analysis is used to determine the Pd loading of the catalysts. Pd@SS-CNR shows a Pd loading of 9.2 wt%, and the control samples of Pd@CNP and Pd@XC72 prepared by using CNP and commercial XC-72 as supports at the same conditions have Pd loadings of 9.4 and 10.0 wt%, repectively, which are
Adv. Mater. 2019, 1900440
© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1900440 (5 of 7)
close to that of Pd@SS-CNR (Table S2, Supporting Information). The catalytic activities of these catalysts are evaluated by the dehydrogenation of aqueous FA solution in the presence of sodium formate (SF) as a promoter (Figure S28, Supporting Information). Comparing to Pd@CNP and Pd@XC72, Pd@ SS-CNR with a hierarchical superstructure shows a much higher catalytic activity, which is about 1.8 and 6.3 times to Pd@CNP and Pd@XC72, respectively (Figure 4g). Even at 30 °C, a gaseous mixture of 144 mL (H2:CO2 = 1:1, Figures S29 and S30, Supporting Information) is released in 2 min from the aqueous FA–SF solution (FA:SF = 1:2.5, nPd/nFA = 0.017), corresponding to a turnover frequency (TOF) of 1878 h−1. Notably, when the temperature is increased to 60 °C, the reaction can be finished in only 30 s, giving an exceptionally high TOF of 7200 h−1 with 100% H2 selectivity, which is comparable to the most active heterogeneous catalysts for FA dehydrogenation (Figure 4h).[37–39] The excellent catalytic activity for FA dehydrogenation is attributed to the unique features of hierarchical structure. SS-CNR assembled by 1D porous carbon nanorod exhibits a much higher surface area and larger pore volume for immobilizing Pd NPs, giving a smaller size of Pd NPs with uniform dispersion when compared to the individual carbon NPs as a support (Figure S31, Supporting Information). During the catalytic process, the space between the nanorods of Pd@ SS-CNR facilitates the access of reactant formic acid and the diffusion of the released gas, resulting in a superior catalytic performance.[30,37] Within the temperature range of 30–60 °C, the apparent activation energy (Ea) of this reaction is estimated to be 38.8 kJ mol−1 (Figure 4i). Pd@SS-CNR exhibits an excellent recyclability and structure stability, which shows no obvious decrease in catalytic performance and change in particle size after 5 cycles (Figures S32 and S33, Supporting Information),
Adv. Mater. 2019, 1900440
© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1900440 (6 of 7)
further demonstrating the advantage of using SS-CNR as a support for excellent Pd catalysts.
In summary, the highly uniform chestnut-shell-like superstructure composed of 1D anisotropic MOF nanorods has been successfully fabricated via the hydrothermal transformation of Zn-MOF-74 nanoparticles. SS-MOFNR can retain the original morphology during carbonization in argon, giving a spherical superstructure of carbon nanorods with hierarchical pores. Compared to the CNP derived from Zn-MOF-74 nanoparticles, SS-CNR shows a much larger BET surface area, pore volume, and a better performance as a support for Pd-immobilized catalysts. Pd@SS-CNR shows an exceptionally high catalytic activity for formic acid dehydrogenation with a TOF as high
as 7200 h−1 at 60 °C. This work opens up a novel strategy for developing spherical superstructures of nanorods for energy storage, catalysis, and other related fields.
